Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract The one-pot hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) of an aqueous sorbitol solution (20 wt%) was studied over Pd (0.5 wt%)/WO x –ZrO2 catalyst at the variable reaction conditions in a continuous mode focusing on the effect of the calcination temperature of tungstated zirconia (1073 and 1223 К), the Pd containing catalyst reduction temperature, as well as on the correlation between their physical-chemical properties and fuel hydrocarbons yield. It was found that sorbitol HDO under reaction conditions such as temperatures 573 and 613 K, hydrogen pressure 4.0 MPa, and WHSV of 1.0 h–1 resulted in the highest yield of C5+ hydrocarbons 76–81 mol% mainly consisting of isoalkanes, cycloalkanes, n–alkanes and arenes. The maximum yield of the targeted isoalkanes and cycloalkanes with RON>70 (34 mol%) along with the minimum amount of undesirable C6–C8 arenes (2 mol%) were obtained at 613 K. Under these conditions the Pd catalyst reduced at 613 K using tungstated zirconia calcined at 1073 K as a support afforded formation of Pd/WO x –ZrO2 with the optimal microtexture, acidity and dispersion of catalytically active phase. Physicochemical properties of the catalyst and support were studied by XRD, low temperature N2 physical adsorption, NH3–TPD, H2–TPR, CO chemisorption, XPS, and CO2–TPD. Keywords Sorbitol Hydrodeoxygenation Biofuels Tungstated zirconia Palladium 1 Introduction Sustainable lignocellulose-derived biofuels are considered to address the climate change and secure energy supply providing an increase of the role of renewable energy and a decrease of the carbon intensity in the transportation sector. According to the estimation of the World Energy Council (BP Statistical Review of World Energy) in 2018 [1] the consumption of petroleum-based energy increased by 2.9% along with the concurrent greenhouse gas emissions growth by 2.0%. It was proposed that the global environmental situation will be got worse and the fuel reserves will be depleted in fifty years if the consumption of fossil fuels is maintained at the current rate [1]. The EU countries concerned with this forecast have developed an ‘energy strategy’ in November 2018 to encourage the use of renewable energy sources [2]. The Directive 2009/28/EC [3] and proposals for the Directive [4] declared that the renewable energy consumption will increase to 27% of the total energy consumption by 2030. The EU transport sector will consume up to 14% of all renewable energy, and half of that will be generated using crop-derived biofuels. Thus the development of catalytic HDO of lignocellulosic biomass (cellulose, hemicellulose, and lignin) into high-quality second-generation biofuels can be considered as one of the most promising way to meet the current requirements [5,6]. Development of the biorefinery concept for production of biofuels enforced the development of new catalytic processes capable to convert selectively biomass-derived oxygenates into C5+ hydrocarbons with research octane number (RON) >70. One of promising way for production of alkanes considered in the literature involves HDO of C6 and C5 polyols formed by hydrogenation of hexoses and pentoses, respectively, obtained in turn by hydrolysis of carbohydrate components of lignocellulose [7–9]. It was shown that selective hydrogenolysis of C–O bonds of sorbitol resulting in n–hexane can be achieved over catalytic systems containing noble metals and oxophilic oxides, for example, Ru–MoO3− x /С [10] and Ir–ReO x /SiO2 + HZSM–5 [11] with a high yield ca. 80 and 95 mol%, respectively. Low octane number of alkanes can be increased by hydroisomerization (HIS) into isoalkanes. Industrial technologies for n–hexane HIS, such as Par-Isom (Pt/SО4 2−–ZrO2 catalyst by UOP), EMICT (Pt/WO3–ZrO2 catalyst by ExxonMobil), etc. enables production of high-octane methylpentanes and dimethylbutanes [12,13]. The obtained isomers are valuable components of commercial gasoline; however, their two-stage production from sorbitol (HDO + HIS) requires significant capital expenditures. A more promising way is one-pot hydroconversion of sorbitol to fuel hydrocarbons performed over Ni/HZSM–5 catalysts in an autoclave at a temperature 513 K and hydrogen pressure 4.0 MPa [14, 15]. Although the yield of liquid alkanes under these conditions attained 36 mol% with iso-hexane fraction being ca. 60% of them, catalyst deactivation caused by coke deposition on active sites and sintering of nickel particles seriously limited a broad application of this approach. Hydroprocessing of sorbitol in a flow reactor at temperature of 553 K, hydrogen pressure of 4.0 MPa and WHSV 2.25 h−1 on Ni/HZSM–5 [16] and Ni/HZSM–5/MCM–41 [17] catalysts yields 70.6 and 28.6 mol% organic fractions containing oxygenates, naphthalenes, cyclic olefins (10 and 23%, respectively) and alkyl benzenes (36 and 57%, respectively). Even if these unsaturated and monoaromatic hydrocarbons are characterized by RONs higher than 80 [18] and 90 [19], respectively, their amount in compounded motor fuels have to be regulated according to the European standard EN 228:2008. In addition, currently the presence of low-octane number oxygenates (hexanones, hexanoic acid [20]) and naphthalenes have to be excluded in gasoline. For these reasons additional upgrading of organic fractions obtained during hydroprocessing on nickel catalysts is required. HDO of sorbitol in a flow mode over the catalyst prepared by mixing Ni/HZSM–5 and Ni/silica–gel (1:1 by mass) provides a gasoline yield 46.9 mol% at 573 K, hydrogen pressure of 4.0 MPa and WHSV 0.75 h−1 [21]. It was shown that the gasoline yield decreased whereas the methane yield increased after 40 h of TOS due to aggregation or migration of Ni particles on the surface of the composite catalyst. The fraction of aromatic hydrocarbons in gasoline does not exceed 1%. However, a high content of C5–C12 n–alkanes in gasoline (up to 88%) requires its subsequent HIS. A stable yield of the С5–С7 hydrocarbon fraction (57 mol%) that consisted mainly of cycloalkanes (38%) and isoalkanes (25%) was observed in HDO of sorbitol over the Pd/WO x –Al2O3 catalyst in a flow reactor at a temperature 653 K, hydrogen pressure 4.0 MPa, and WHSV of 1.0 h–1 in 8 h [22]. However, significant formation of by-products (CO2, CO, С1–С4 alkanes) through hydrodecarboxylation, hydrodecarbonylation, and hydrogenolysis of C–C bonds occurred in the presence of this catalyst. Compared to the WO x –Al2O3 support, WO x –ZrO2 differed by higher thermal stability, acidity [23] and metal-support interactions [24] resulting in Pd/WO x –ZrO2 catalyst with bifunctional properties widely used in hydrodechlorination [25], oxidation of ethylene to acetic acid [26], HDO of ethylene glycol in an aqueous medium [27] and HIS of n–butane [28], n–hexane [29], and n–heptane [30]. Pt/WO x –ZrO2 catalyst was shown to be able to selectively cleave C–O bonds in HDO of glycerol [31] and tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol [32]. It was reported WO x –Pd/ZrO2 catalysts were able to selectively break C–O bonds in 1.4-anhydroerythritol [33], while Ru/WO x –ZrO2 catalyst was successfully applied for guaiacol HDO [34]. Therefore, it can be assumed that hydroconversion of sorbitol over the Pd/WO x –ZrO2 system can result in a high yield of hydrocarbon products enriched by n–hexane. In turn, this catalytic system can be also effective in HIS of hydrocarbon products; therefore, it can be successfully used to combine both HDO and HIS in one-pot process to obtain gasoline fuel components from C6 and C5 polyols. The calcination temperature of the WO x –ZrO2 support and the reduction temperature of Pd/WO x –ZrO2 catalysts play an important role in order to tune catalytic activity in HIS. It was shown the crystal phase composition, as well as textural and acidic properties of Pt/WO x –ZrO2 catalyst can be controlled through variation of the WO x –ZrO2 calcination temperature [35–38]. Changes in the reduction temperature of the supported metal catalysts enabled the control of the dispersion [39] and active metal oxidation state [40], as well as the distribution of Lewis (LAS) and Bronsted (BAS) acid sites on support surface [41]. A choice of the optimal calcination and reduction temperatures for Pd/WO x –ZrO2 catalyst mainly depends on the nature of alkane involved in HIS reaction. The Pd/WO x –ZrO2 catalyst with increased acidity reduced at 623 K with the support calcined at 1073 K is typically used for HIS of n–hexane [42] while Pd/WO x –ZrO2 reduced at 573 K with the support calcined at 1223 K and lower acidity was used for a more reactive n–heptane HIS [41]. In [22], it was found that products obtained by HDO of sorbitol over the Pd/WO x –Al2O3 catalyst included n–hexane and n–heptane which was formed via a condensation reaction. Therefore, the aim of the current study is to investigate the effect of the conditions for preparation and reduction of Pd/WO x –ZrO2 catalysts, along with the effect of the reaction temperature, on the yield and composition of the hydrocarbon products obtained by one-pot HDO of sorbitol in a continuous mode. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Zirconium hydroxide was precipitated from aqueous solution of zirconium oxychloride (ZrOCl2 ·8H2O, Aldrich, >98 wt%) by adding aqueous ammonia solution (pH = 10) at vigorous mixing. A constant pH of 9.5 ± 0.5 was maintained by dropping a concentrated ammonia solution (25 wt% of ammonia). The pH control during precipitation was carried out using a Seven Easy pH meter S20–K (Mettler Toledo). The resulting precipitate was stored in the mother liquor for 1 h, filtered, washed with distilled water to remove residual Cl− ions (after each wash, a few drops of AgNO3 solution were added to the liquid filtrate until no evidence of AgCl could be detected), and dried at 373 K for 5 h. The WO x –ZrO2 support was prepared by impregnating zirconium hydroxide with an aqueous solution of ammonium metatungstate ((NH4)6H2W12O40, Aldrich, ≥85 wt% WO3) followed by molding, drying at 393 K for 3 h, and calcining in air at 1073 and 1223 K for 2 h. The content of WO3 in the calcined supports was 25 wt%. The supports were designated as WZ(TC), where W is WO x , Z is ZrO2, and ТC is the WZ calcination temperature. The Pd/WZ(1073) and Pd/WZ(1223) catalysts were synthesized by the incipient wetness impregnation of the supports with an aqueous solution of H2PdCl4 (50 mg Pd/cm3) (PdCl2, Krastsvetmet, ≥99.9%) followed by drying at 393 K for 3 h and calcining in air flow at 723 K for 1 h. After that, the catalyst samples were treated with hydrogen (50 cm3/min flow rate) for 2 h at working temperatures 573 and 613 K. The palladium loading in the reduced samples was 0.5 wt%. The final catalysts were designated as Pd/WZ(TC)–TR, where ТR is the reduction temperature. 2.2 Support characterization Textural characteristics of the WZ(TC) supports (specific surface area, adsorption pore volume, average pore diameter) were calculated from the nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms obtained by N2 physisorption at 77 K using a Sorptomatic-1900 instrument (Carlo Erba). The specific surface area (S BET) of these supports was estimated by BET method in the relative pressure range of 0.05–0.33. The adsorption pore volume (V ads) of the WZ(TC) supports was determined at a relative pressure 0.990. The average pore diameter of these supports was calculated from the expression 4V ads/S BET. The crystallographic phase composition of the WZ(TC) supports was determined using the Bruker D8 Advance PXRD with CuKα radiation (0.15406 nm wavelength) equipped with a LynxEye linear position sensitive detector (40 kV voltage and 40 mA filament current). The diffraction patterns were recorded in the following mode: a 20–70° scanning range of 2θ angles, a 0.02° scanning step, and 2 s/point signal accumulation time. Crystallographic phases were identified using the ICDD PDF-2 powder diffraction database. The composition of crystal phases and the crystallite size were calculated by the Rietveld method using the TOPAS 4.2 software (Bruker). The acidic properties of the WZ(TC) supports were investigated by temperature-programmed ammonia desorption (NH3–TPD) using a Micromeritics AutoChem–2920 chemisorption analyzer equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The samples were heated in helium to 773 K, held at this temperature for 1 h, cooled in helium stream to 373 K, which was followed by ammonia adsorption for 1 h using a 10 vol% NH3 – 90 vol% He mixture. Ammonia was desorbed in the temperature range of 373–773 K at a heating rate of 10 K/min. Weakly bound ammonia was removed by helium blowing for 1 h at 373 K. The number of weak, medium, and strong acid sites on the WZ(TC) support surface was estimated with respect to the amount of ammonia desorbed at 373–473, 473–623, and 623–773 K, respectively [31]. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The S BET of the fresh and spent catalysts was determined from an analysis of nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms obtained by N2 physisorption on an ASAP–2020 (Micromeritics) vacuum static unit at 77 K. The S BET of these catalysts was estimated by BET method in the relative pressure range of 0.05–0.33. The study of temperature-programmed reduction by hydrogen (H2–TPR) of the Pd/WZ(TC) catalysts calcined at 723 K, evaluation of the palladium dispersion in the reduced Pd/WZ(TC)–TR catalysts, their acidic and basic properties were performed using the Micromeritics AutoChem–2920 chemisorption analyzer. H2–TPR of the Pd/WZ(TC) catalysts calcined at 723 K was performed in a flow mixture of 10 vol% H2 – 90 vol% Ar from room temperature until 573 or 613 K at a heating rate 10 K/min, and after that, the hydrogen absorption profiles were recorded. Dispersion of palladium in the reduced Pd/WZ(TC)–TR catalysts cooled till room temperature was estimated by pulsed chemisorption of carbon monoxide. A mixture of 10 vol% CO – 90 vol% He was pulsed into the helium carrier gas flow at regular intervals. The palladium dispersion was calculated using the results of CO chemisorption in accordance with the CO:Pd = 1 stoichiometry [24, 25]. The dispersion value obtained was recalculated into the average diameter of palladium particles considering their spherical shape [43]. X-ray photoelectron spectra were recorded on a SPECS (Germany) photoelectron spectrometer using an MgKa (hν = 1253.6 eV, 150 W) source. The binding energy (BE) scale was preliminarily calibrated by position of the peaks of gold and copper core levels: Au4f7/2 – 84.0 eV and Cu2p3/2 – 932.67 eV. The residual gas pressure did not exceed 8 × 10−7 Pa. The measurements were carried out both for the oxidized samples and after their reduction in hydrogen (P(H2) = 10 kPa, T = 573 K, t = 1 h) in the high-pressure cell of a spectrometer intended for treatment in various gas media at a pressure up to 101.3 kPa and temperature 323–773 K. Therewith, the samples were rubbed in stainless steel gauze that was spot-welded on a standard holder. After cooling in hydrogen and its evacuation, the samples were transferred to the analyzer chamber for measuring the photoelectron spectra. To reveal the chemical (charge) state of elements on the surface of samples narrow Zr4p+W4f, Zr3d, W4d, C1s, Pd3d+Zr3p, and O1s regions were measured. The BE of peaks was calibrated by the position of the C1s peak (BE = 284.8 eV) corresponding to the surface hydrocarbon-like deposits (C–C and C–H bonds) [44]. The relative content of elements on the surface of samples and their atomic ratio were estimated from integrated intensities of photoelectron lines corrected for the corresponding atomic sensitivity factors [45]. The number and strength of acid sites over the reduced Pd/WZ(TC)–TR catalysts were determined by NH3–TPD technique. Preparation of the catalysts for the study and adsorption of ammonia were performed in accordance with the procedure used to study the acidic properties of the WZ(TC) supports (Section 2.2). Desorption of ammonia from the surface of the reduced samples was performed in the temperature range of 373–773 K at a heating rate of 10 K/min (Section 2.2). To study the basic properties of the Pd/WZ(TC)–573 catalysts by CO2–TPD technique, the samples were heated in helium stream to 773 K, stored for 0.5 h at this temperature, cooled in helium stream to 373 K, and then carbon dioxide adsorption was performed for 1 h using a 10 vol% CO2 – 90 vol% He mixture. Weakly bound carbon dioxide was removed by helium blowing for 1 h at 373 K. Carbon dioxide desorption was performed in the temperature range of 373–773 K at a heating rate of 10 K/min. The carbon content in the spent catalysts was determined by automatic coulometric titration relative to the pH value on the AN-7560M express analyzer (Measuring Technology Ltd.). A weighed portion of the catalyst was burned in a tubular furnace in a stream of impurity-free oxygen. Carbon dioxide formed during carbon combustion entered the electrolytic cell of the analyzer with an oxygen flow and was absorbed in it by the solution containing SrCl2 and KCl. Oxidation of the solution changed the EMF of the electrode system, which was converted by pH meter into a signal that included a stabilized current source. The current pulses caused reduction of H+ ions at the cathode, which neutralized the acid formed during carbon dioxide absorption. The amount of electricity required for neutralization was recorded using a scale indicator calibrated in wt% carbon. 2.4 Catalytic testing Hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) of 20 wt% aqueous sorbitol solution (Sigma-Aldrich, ≥99%) was performed in a continuous mode in an isothermal tubular flow reactor with a fixed catalyst bed (0.2–0.5 mm fraction). Similar grain size catalysts are often used to study HDO of sorbitol under flow mode conditions allowing to avoid mass transfer limitations [46,47]. During reactor loading, catalyst portions of 0.6 g were diluted with 0.6 g quartz (0.8–1.0 mm fraction). The test conditions for the Pd/WZ(TС)–573 and Pd/WZ(TС)–613 catalysts were as follows: hydrogen pressure of 4.0 MPa, WHSV of 1.0 h−1, H2/feed volume ratio of 2400 Nm3/m3, duration of 6.0 h, and temperature of 573 or 613 K, respectively. The temperature of 613 K was taken as the maximum temperature for reduction of the catalysts and their testing in HDO of sorbitol (instead of 623 K) to suppress possible side reactions of hydrocarbon hydrocracking. The condensed products were collected in a water-cooled condenser, where gas and liquid phases were separated. The volume of the gaseous products was measured using a drum-type gas meter, and their mass was calculated from the values of volume and density in accordance with the ideal gas law and taking into account the results of gas chromatography (GC). The GC analysis of the gaseous products was performed using a two-channel GKh–1000 instrument (Khromos) [48]. To identify the reaction products, H2, CO, CO2, CH4, C2H6, C3H8, C4H10 (all gases with a purity of 99.99%, PJSC “Novosibirsk Chemical Concentrates Plant”), C5–C10 n–alkanes, C5–C9 isoalkanes, C6–C9 cycloalkanes, C6–C8 arenes (all hydrocarbons with a purity of 99%, “Sigma-Aldrich”) were used as standards. The contents of H2, CO, and CO2 were determined using a packed column filled with Porapak R (3 m length, 4 mm inner diameter), helium as a carrier gas and TCD at an evaporator temperature of 473 K and a detector temperature of 423 K. Hydrocarbons С1–С10 were determined using the Agilent Technologies capillary column with a DB-1 phase (60 m length, 0.25 mm inner diameter, 0.50 μm stationary phase thickness), argon as a carrier gas, and a flame ionization detector (FID). The temperature of the evaporator and FID was 473 K. The temperature program of the columns was as follows: holding at 313 K for 5 min, heating at a rate of 4 K/min to 423 K, holding at 423 K for 15 min. The mass of the liquid products was determined using an analytical balance. The reaction products present in the aqueous phase were identified by 1H and 13C NMR spectroscopy. Spectra were recorded on an Avance–400 (Bruker) NMR spectrometer at the Larmor frequency of 400 MHz (1H) or 101 MHz (13C) in a pulsed mode. Quantitative determination of the reaction products in the aqueous phase was carried out using a Khromos GKh–1000 gas chromatograph equipped with a ValcoBond VB-Wax capillary column (60 m length, 0.32 mm inner diameter, 0.50 μm stationary phase thickness) and FID. The analysis was performed in the temperature programmed mode (holding at 323 K for 12 min, heating at 10 K/min to 513 K, holding at 513 K for 31 min) using argon as a carrier gas at the evaporator and FID temperature of 473 K and 503 K respectively. The yield of the products in conversion of sorbitol (in mol% of carbon) was calculated as the ratio of the number of moles of carbon in the product to the number of moles of carbon in sorbitol supplied to the reactor [49]. The error in the reaction product yield was ±0.5 mol%. The calculation of the composition of the products obtained by HDO of sorbitol is described in detail in the Supplementary Materials. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Effect of WZ support calcination temperature on textural characteristics, crystal phase composition and acidic properties of WZ support Samples of the WZ support calcined at temperatures from 1073 to 1223 K were studied by low-temperature nitrogen adsorption, XRD, and NH3–TPD techniques. The results for the WZ support samples studied by low-temperature nitrogen adsorption are summarized in Table S1. These data show that an increase of the calcination temperature of the WZ support from 1073 to 1223 K resulted in a decrease of the specific surface area from 65 to 37 m2/g and the adsorption pore volume from 0.26 to 0.17 cm3/g, while the average pore size slightly increases from 16.2 to 18.3 nm. These changes in textural characteristics of the WZ support could be caused by partial destruction of the pore structure at higher calcination temperature [50, 51] and were accompanied by an increase in the surface density of W atoms from 10 to 18 W atom/nm2 (Table S1). The XRD data of the support samples are presented in Table S2, with the diffraction patterns shown in Fig. S1. The XRD analysis showed that the crystal phase composition changed after calcination. As the calcination temperature of the WZ support increased from 1073 to 1223 K, the content of the tetragonal phase of zirconia (t–ZrO2) decreased from 90 to 31%, while fractions of monoclinic ZrO2 (m–ZrO2) as well as the monoclinic phase of tungsten oxide (m–WO3) increased to 49% and twofold, correspondingly (Table S2). At the same time, an increase in the calcination temperature of WZ from 1073 to 1223 K resulted in a significant growth of t–ZrO2 and m–WO3 crystallites size from 11.8 to 21.7 nm and from 23.6 to 55.0 nm, respectively (Table S2). Apparently, as shown in [39,52], during calcination of the WZ support, the surface W5+ containing ions are oxidized to W6+ ions. As a result, the zirconia lattice became unstable facilitating migration of W6+ ions and formation of the WO3 phase crystal structure. Since these W6+ ions were responsible for stabilization of the t–ZrO2 phase, their migration benefited zirconia transformations from the tetragonal into monoclinic phase. Thus, the revealed changes in the phase composition of the WZ support affected its textural characteristics (Table S1). Note, that changes in the crystal phase composition and textural properties of the WZ support due to calcination led to corresponding changes in their acid-base properties. The acid-base properties of the surface of the calcined WZ support samples were studied by temperature-programmed desorption of NH3 to estimate the number of weak, medium, and strong acid sites, as well as the surface integral acidity. NH3–TPD profiles for the WZ support samples calcined at different temperatures indicate that acidic properties are most pronounced in the WZ(1073) sample calcined at a lower temperature of 1073 K (Fig. S2). The total values of desorbed ammonia calculated from the areas of these profiles per mass unit (μmol/g) and per unit of the surface area of the WZ support (μmol/m2) are summarized in Table S3. When the support calcination temperature increased from 1073 to 1223 K, acidity decreased 2.1- and 1.2-fold per mass and surface unit, respectively. This can be attributed to a decrease of the specific surface area and the content of the t–ZrO2 phase during calcination of the WZ support. The distribution of acid sites on the WZ support surface did not change when the calcination temperature increased from 1073 to 1223 K (Fig. S2). Analysis of the NH3–TPD data (Table S3) indicated that acidity of WZ support calcined at 1073 or 1223 K was mainly determined by the weak and medium acid sites exhibiting maximum thermal desorption of ammonia at 453–463 and 523–533 K, respectively. Note that strong surface acid sites on the WZ support calcined at these temperatures were detected in negligible amounts (Table S3). Thus, calcination of tungstated zirconia in the range of 1073–1223 K changed its textural parameters and phase composition decreasing its specific surface area, adsorption pore volume and total acidity of the surface sites. 3.2 Effect of WZ support calcination temperature on reducibility, Pd dispersion, and acid-base properties of Pd/WZ catalysts The S BET values of the Pd/WZ(1073) and Pd/WZ(1223) catalysts calcined at 723 K are shown in Table 1 . Comparison of these values with the corresponding S BET values in Table S1 indicates that the incorporation of palladium into the WZ(1073) and WZ(1223) supports did not lead to significant changes in the specific surface area. Palladium catalysts on the basis of WZ(1073) and WZ(1223) supports were studied by H2–TPR. The H2–TPR profiles of Pd/WZ(1073) and Pd/WZ(1223) shown in Fig. 1 indicate temperature regions of hydrogen evolution at 338–348 K and hydrogen absorption at temperatures above 573 K. In addition, the H2–TPR profile of Pd/WZ(1223) was characterized with additional hydrogen absorption in the range of 348–398 K. A negative peak due to the decomposition of the β-phase of palladium hydride [27,29,41,42] was less intensive in the H2–TPR profile of Pd/WZ(1073) (Fig. 1, curve 1) compared to Pd/WZ(1223) (Fig. 1, curve 2). This result may indicate agglomeration of palladium metal particles on WZ(1223). The Pd/WZ(1223) catalyst is characterized by a lower S BET (31 m2/g, Table 1) and, accordingly, a higher surface density of W atoms (21 W atom/nm2, Table 1) compared to Pd/WZ(1073) catalyst (SBET= 62 m2/g, 10 W atom/nm2, Table 1) [26,53]. The hydrogen adsorption region at 348–398 K in the H2–TPR profile of Pd/WZ(1223) catalyst (Fig. 1, curve 2) resulted from the reduction of palladium oxide [27,29,41,42] on WZ(1223). The hydrogen absorption region at 573–613 K in the H2–TPR profiles of palladium catalysts (Fig. 1) corresponds to the beginning of the reduction of WO x clusters (WO3→WO2.9) on WZ(1073) and WZ(1223) supports [31,39,41,54]. Agglomeration of WO3 crystallites on the zirconia surface enhanced as the calcination temperature of the WZ support increased from 1073 to 1223 K (Table S2). Therefore, this process led to a decrease of the size of the WO x clusters on the WZ(1223) support [53]. As a result, the amount of hydrogen required for their reduction over the Pd/WZ(1223) catalyst decreased [31,54]. Table 2 shows the values of Pd dispersion and the average diameter of palladium particles in Pd/WZ(1073) and Pd/WZ(1223) catalysts reduced at 573 and 613 K determined by CO chemisorption technique. It was found that all samples exhibited low Pd dispersion due to a large amount of WO3 oxide in the support [31,34]. At the same time, the Pd/WZ(1073)–573 catalyst differed from the Pd/WZ(1223)–573 catalyst by a marginally higher dispersion of the supported metal and, hence, a smaller average particle size. This may be attributed to better dispersion of palladium particles over WZ(1073) due to lower density of W atoms (Table S1) and larger amount of the t–ZrO2 phase (Table S2) [34,55] compared to WZ(1223). It should be noted that as the catalyst reduction temperature increased to 613 K the dispersion of the supported metal insignificantly decreased and, hence, its particle size increased (Table 2). This can be attributed to the effect of WO3− x nonstoichiometric oxides formed during reduction of the Pd/WZ(TC) catalysts at temperatures exceeding 573 K (Fig. 1) impeding availability of the palladium metal particles for CO chemisorption due to partial decoration by WO3 oxide [39,56,57]. Thus, on the basis of the experimental results and literature data [22,58,59] one can expect that a lower yield of CO and higher yields of isoalkanes and cycloalkanes will be obtained during sorbitol HDO over the Pd/WZ(1073)–573 catalyst characterized with a higher metal dispersion. On the contrary, HDO of sorbitol in the presence of Pd/WZ(1223)–573 is anticipated to result in lower yields of isoalkanes and cycloalkanes [22,59] and a higher yield of CO [58]. The reduction effects were investigated by XPS. Fig. 2 displays XPS spectra in the region of Zr(4p) + W(4f) for Pd/WZ catalysts subjected to different thermal treatments. One can observe that the W4f XPS spectrum is fitted with two doublets corresponding to different oxidation states of tungsten as indicated by the overlapped individual peaks obtained after deconvolution with spin-orbit splitting of W4f peaks of 2.1 eV. The first doublet comprises a peak centered at a BE of 35.6 eV that is assigned to W6+ species [29,32,52,55], whereas the second doublet includes a peak centered at a BE of 34.4 eV that could be attributed to W5+ species [29, 52, 60, 61]. Therefore, both types of tungsten oxidation states (W5+ and W6+) present simultaneously on the surface of the Pd/WZ(1073) and Pd/WZ(1223) catalysts calcined at 723 K. It additionally confirms the assumption on oxidation of the W5+ surface species into W6+ during calcination of the WZ(TC) supports, provided earlier when discussing the phase composition of the WZ(1073) and WZ(1223) supports (Section 3.1). The fractions of W6+ on the surface of calcined Pd/WZ(1073) and Pd/WZ(1223) samples (Fig. 2, spectra 1 and 3) are 88 and 75%, respectively. After their reduction (Fig. 2, spectra 2 and 4) the fraction of W6+ in Pd/WZ(1073)–573 and Pd/WZ(1223)–573 samples decreases to 82 and 72%, respectively. It should be noted that efficiency of Pd/WZ(1073)–TR and Pd/WZ(1223)–TR catalysts (TR = 573 and 613 K) in HDO of sorbitol at different temperatures may depend on the Pd particle size and oxidative state as well as on the surface acidic properties. Fig. 3 shows the NH3–TPD profiles for the Pd/WZ(TC)–TR catalysts. Table 3 summarizes data on the number of weak, medium and strong acid sites expressed by the amount of desorbed ammonia per mass and surface area units for the Pd/WZ(TC)–TR catalysts. Comparison of the data in Tables S3 and 3 as well as of the NH3–TPD profiles for the supports (Fig. S2) and the corresponding palladium catalysts (Fig. 3) showed that deposition of palladium on tungstated zirconia promoted redistribution of acid sites by their strength and amount on the surface of the Pd/WZ(TC)–TR catalysts. The shift in the maximum of ammonia thermal desorption from 523–533 K for Pd-free supports (Fig. S2, curves 1, 2) to 450–480 K for palladium catalysts (Fig. 3, curves 1–4) indicates a qualitative change in the acidity of the Pd/WZ(TC)–TR catalysts. At the same time, the data in Tables S3 and 3 show that the reduced catalysts differ from the supports providing larger number of weak, medium, and strong acid sites and, consequently, a higher value of the total acidity amounting to 25–40 μmol/g versus 0.6 μmol/m2. These data showed quantitatively a change in the acidity of the Pd/WZ(TC)–TR catalysts depending on the reduction temperature and Pd presence. According to the literature the WZ supports containing <25 wt% WO3 and calcined at 1073 K [28,29,38] or 1173 K [62, 63] can possess both LAS and BAS. It was found that the total acidity of tungstated zirconia and the total number of LAS and BAS increased when the calcination temperature of the WZ support decreased (e.g., from 1173 to 1073 K) or WO3 oxide loading increased (e.g., from 10 to 20 wt%) [63]. In addition, it was shown [28, 41] that palladium deposition on the WZ(TC) supports followed by its reduction promoted formation of new LAS and BAS on the WZ surface. Thus, a study of ZW18Pd catalysts (W = 18 wt% and TC = 1073 K) with a different Pd content ranging between 0.1 and 6 wt% performed by redox cycles O2/H2 and EPR spectroscopy showed that presence of palladium facilitated reduction of W6+ cations to W5+ cations in W x O y surface clusters [28]. It was noted that an increase of the reduction temperature from 573 to 773 K gave a rise of the yield of С1–С4 alkanes in n–heptane HIS over the Pd/WO3/ZrO2 catalysts (Pd loading = 0.1–1 wt%, WO3 = 15 wt%, TC = 1223 K). This enhancement of n–heptane cracking reaction resulted from formation of additional LAS by partial reduction of W6+ cations in these catalysts [41]. The reduction of the Pd/WZ(TC) catalysts generated the surface W5+ cations which can be responsible for formation of new LAS. Simultaneously also BAS can be formed on Pd/WZ(TC) catalysts under reduction conditions due to interactions of palladium hydrides and W x Oy clusters contained W5+ and W6+ cations following [28]: PdH(s) +W6+ x O3 y → Pd(s) + W5+W6+ x -1О3 у Н+ Taking into account the literature data [28,29,41,63] and the XPS results, it can be assumed that an increase in the acidity of the Pd/WZ(TC)–TR catalysts detected by NH3–TPD can be associated with the formation of additional LAS and BAS on the catalyst surface. Since WZ(TC) supports containing WO3 ≥25 wt% are not transparent to IR radiation [38], it was difficult to reliably estimate the amount of LAS and BAS on the surface of Pd/WZ(TC)–TR catalysts by FTIR spectroscopy of adsorbed probe molecules. Dependence of the acidic properties of the Pd/WZ(TC)–TR catalysts on the calcination temperature of the WZ(TC) supports is shown in Tables S3 and 3. Both the WZ(1073) support and Pd/WZ(1073)–TR catalysts are characterized by higher acidity. The amount of ammonia desorbed from the Pd/WZ(1073)–TR catalysts was twofold (by 124 μmol/g) and 1.2 fold (by 0.5 μmol/m2) higher than that desorbed from the Pd/WZ(1223)–TR catalysts (Table 3). Although an increase in the calcination temperature of the WZ support from 1073 to 1223 K caused a decrease of the acidity of the corresponding palladium catalysts, no redistribution of acid sites by their strength was observed. All Pd/WZ(TC)–TR catalysts demonstrated a similar distribution of acid sites characterized by predominance of medium sites over weak and strong ones (Fig. 3 and Table 3). At the same time, the reduction temperature of palladium catalysts has virtually no effect on their acidic properties (Fig. 3 and Table 3). The results obtained were in agreement with literature data [14,15,22] inferring that sorbitol HDO in the presence of Pd/WZ(1073)–TR catalysts of higher acidity and Pd/WZ(1223)–TR catalysts of lower acidity will proceed with higher and lower yields of targeted hydrocarbons (isoalkanes and cycloalkanes), respectively. The CO2–TPD profiles of the Pd/WZ(TC)–573 catalysts with calcination temperatures 1073 or 1223 K are presented in Fig. 4 . The amount and density of desorbed carbon dioxide were presented in Table 4 . The data in Fig. 4 and Table 4 showed that increase of the calcination temperature of the WZ support from 1073 to 1223 K led to decrease of a number of basic sites, as well as their density and strength on the surface of the supported palladium catalyst. The latter was demonstrated as a shift in the maximum thermal desorption of carbon dioxide from 526 K for the Pd/WZ(1073)–573 catalyst (Fig. 4, curve 1) to 488 K for the Pd/WZ(1223)–573 catalyst (Fig. 4, curve 2). Thus, it can be assumed that the yield of products of condensation reaction in sorbitol HDO was higher in the presence of the Pd/WZ(1073)–573 catalyst with higher basicity compared to that in the presence of the Pd/WZ(1223)–573 catalyst. 3.3.1 HDO of sorbitol over Pd/WZ catalysts Efficiency and stability of the Pd/WZ(TC)–573 and Pd/WZ(TC)–613 catalysts in sorbitol HDO were studied at 573 and 613 K, respectively, at hydrogen pressure of 4.0 MPa and WHSV of 1.0 h–1 during time-on-stream (TOS) 6 h. All catalysts showed almost complete conversion of sorbitol into carbon oxides (CO, CO2), light C1–C4 alkanes, С5+ hydrocarbons, methanol, and water in TOS of 1 h (Table 5 ). According to the GC analysis the С5–С9 hydrocarbons fraction contained n–alkanes, isoalkanes, cycloalkanes, and arenes at TOS of 6 h (Table 6 ). Variety of products obtained by HDO of sorbitol over palladium catalysts indicates that they are formed through a set of reactions due to bifunctional catalytic properties and specific reaction conditions. Thus, along with hydrogen the gas phase formed over the Pd/WZ(TC)–TR catalysts contained the products generated in the following reactions: a) dehydration–hydrogenation (DHH) of sorbitol (1) C6H14O6 + 6H2 → C6H14 + 6H2O b) hydrodecarbonylation and hydrodecarboxylation (HDC) of sorbitol (2) C6H14O6 + 4H2 → C5H12 + CO + 5H2O (3) C6H14O6 + 3H2 → C5H12 + CO2 + 4H2O c) formation of C–C bonds via aldol condensation (AC), DHH and hydrogenation [64,65] (4) where * in Eq 4 indicates intermediate reaction products not found in the condensed flow coming from the reactor d) isomerization of С5–C9 alkanes (5) n-C5H12 ⇌ 2-MB (6) n-C6H14 ⇌ DMBs ⇌ MPs (7) n-C7H16 ⇌ DMPs ⇌ MHexs ⇌ 3-EP (8) n-C8H18 ⇌ DMHexs ⇌ 2-M-3-EP ⇌ MHeps ⇌ 3-EHex (9) n-C9H20 ⇌ TMHexs ⇌ DMHeps ⇌ 2-M-3-EHex ⇌ 4-EHep ⇌ MOs where the abbreviations in Eqs. (5–9) correspond to the following hydrocarbons: 2-MB – 2-methylbutane; DMBs – dimethylbutanes; MPs – methylpentanes; DMPs – dimethylpentanes; MHexs – methylhexanes; 3-EP – 3-ethylpentane; DMHexs – dimethylhexanes; 2-M-3-EP – 2-methyl-3-ethylpentane; MHeps – methylheptanes; 3-EHex – 3-ethylhexane; TMHexs – trimethylhexanes; DMHeps – dimethylheptanes; 2-M-3-EHex – 2-methyl-3-ethylhexane; 4-EHep – 4-ethylheptane; MOs – methyloctanes a) cyclization of С6–C9 alkanes (10) (11) (12) (13) b) dehydroisomerization (DHIS) of alkylcyclopentanes (14) where R = H, CH3, C2H5 c) dehydrogenation (DH) of dimethylcyclohexanes (15) d) hydrogenolysis (HG) of С–С bonds in hydrocarbons (hydrocracking) (16) C n H2 n +2 + H2 → C m H2 m +2 + C n–m H2( n – m +1), n ≥ 2, m ≥ 1 and e) water-gas shift (WGS) reaction (17) CO2 + H2 ⇌ CO + H2O The aqueous phase formed over Pd/WZ(TC)–573 contained methanol (according to 1H NMR spectra in Fig. S3) formed by the following reactions [66, 67]: (18) CO + 2H2 → CH3OH (19) CO2 + 3H2 → CH3OH + H2O The product distribution obtained by sorbitol HDO in particular С5+ hydrocarbons obtained in the presence of the Pd/WZ(TC)–TR catalysts, was found to be determined by two factors: the support calcination temperature (TC = 1073, 1223 K) and reaction temperature (TR = 573, 613 K) (Tables 5, 6). Evaluation of the effect of each of these factors allowed determining the best TC and TR providing the maximum yields of the targeted products obtained by sorbitol HDO over the corresponding palladium catalyst, such as isoalkanes and cycloalkanes with high octane number. 3.3.2 Effect of WZ support calcination temperature on the catalytic behavior of Pd/WZ catalysts The sorbitol HDO over the Pd/WZ(TC)–573 catalysts at different calcination temperatures of WZ support 1073 and 1273 K was studied at TOS of 1 h to determine the effect of the calcination temperature on the catalytic properties and the product distribution. It was found that C6 hydrocarbons apparently predominated among the sorbitol HDO products due to high activity of tungstated zirconia in the hydrogenolysis of C–O bonds (Table 5) [31–34]. In addition, the amount of С6 hydrocarbons was shown to be lower in the presence of Pd/WZ(1073)–573 (35.8 mol%) compared to Pd/WZ(1223)–573 (40.9 mol%); however, the amount of С7+ hydrocarbons over the former catalyst (35.7 mol%) was higher than for the latter one (27.5 mol%) (Table 5). A similar yield of С1–С4 alkanes (12.8 and 14.7 mol%) and С5 alkanes (9.2 and 8.9 mol%) regardless the WZ calcination temperature (Table 5) suggested that С6 and С7+ hydrocarbons are a result of АС and DHH reactions (Eq. 1 and Eq 4) over Pd/WZ(TC)–573. This assumption is supported by the following considerations. First, investigation of the Pd/WZ(TC)–573 catalysts by CO2–TPD showed that the number of the basic sites responsible for the AC reaction [65, 68] decreased with the WZ support calcination temperature increase from 1073 up to 1223 K (Table 4) [69]. Therefore, a higher yield of the AC reaction products in sorbitol HDO into hydrocarbons involving the intermediate 2-hexanone formation was observed over the more basic Pd/WZ(1073)–573 catalyst compared to a less basic Pd/WZ(1223)–573 catalyst characterized by lower amounts of the AC reaction products [64,65]. Subsequently, С6 oxygenates are directly converted to С6 hydrocarbons over the Pd/WZ(1073)–573 and Pd/WZ(1223)–573 catalysts to a different extent according to the yields of corresponding hydrocarbons over both catalysts (Table 5). Finally Pd/WZ(1073)–573 catalyst with a higher palladium dispersion and acidity exhibited a higher yield of oxygen-free products resulting from the AC reaction as compared to Pd/WZ(1223)–573 with a lower palladium dispersion and acidity [22]. This is also evidenced by the yield of С7+ hydrocarbons over both catalysts (Table 5). Thus, the observed differences in basic and acidic properties, as well as in the size of the supported metal particles over the Pd/WZ(1073)–573 and Pd/WZ(1223)–573 catalysts resulted in a higher (80.7 mol%) and lower (77.3 mol%) yield of С5+ hydrocarbons in sorbitol HDO, correspondingly (Table 5). The yield of inorganic products produced by HDC of sorbitol (CO+CO2) on the Pd/WZ(1073)–573 catalyst was 6.5 mol% being less prominent than on Pd/WZ(1223)–573 (7.9 mol%) (Table 5). Probably an increase of the calcination temperature of the WZ support from 1073 to 1223 K led to a decrease of palladium dispersion in Pd/WZ(TC)–573 in turn enhancing hydrodecarbonylation of sorbitol (Eq. 2) [58]. However, the amounts of CO2 (1.5 and 1.4 mol%, respectively) and methanol (0.1 and 0.2 mol%, respectively) are comparable in the presence of Pd/WZ(1223)–573 and Pd/WZ(1073)–573 catalysts (Table 5). Apparently a change in the textural properties of Pd/WZ(TC)–573 catalysts with an increase of WZ support calcination temperature did not affect CO2 hydrogenation to methanol (Eq. 19) [70]. The composition of С5–С9 fractions formed in sorbitol HDO over Pd/WZ(TC)–573 catalysts was shown to depend on the calcination temperature of the support attributed to changes in the texture and acidity of Pd/WZ(TC)–573 catalysts (Table 6). The Pd/WZ(1073)–573 catalyst caused formation of larger amounts of isoalkanes (22.6 mol%), cycloalkanes (12.6 mol%), and arenes (2.5 mol%) compared to Pd/WZ(1223)–573 catalyst (17.9, 7.6 and 1.2 mol%, respectively) (Table 6). In particular, the yield of the desired hydrocarbons, such as isoalkanes and cycloalkanes with the octane numbers above 70 was higher over the Pd/WZ(1073)–573 catalyst than over the Pd/WZ(1223)–573 catalyst, being 18.1 versus 16.1 mol% (Table 6). Visible differences in the yield of the target hydrocarbons and arenes can be associated with much faster isomerization [28], cyclization [22], DHIS and DH [71] of deoxygenated products of the AC reaction over the Pd/WZ(1073)–573 catalyst with higher Pd dispersion and acidity compared to those over the Pd/WZ(1223)–573 catalyst with lower Pd dispersion and acidity. The latter is consistent with the number of С5–С9 n–alkanes formed in the presence of the Pd/WZ(1073)–573 catalyst which was less (37.2 mol%) compared to that in the presence of the Pd/WZ(1223)–573 catalyst (40.4 mol%) (Table 6). The results of testing the Pd/WZ(TC)–573 catalyst samples in sorbitol HDO showed that calcination of tungstated zirconia at 1073 K and subsequent introduction of palladium over it provided a more efficient catalyst with a higher yield of С5+ products enriched the target hydrocarbons. 3.3.3 Effect of the reaction temperature on the catalytic behavior of Pd/WZ catalysts The Pd/WZ(1073)–TR and Pd/WZ(1223)–TR samples at reduction temperatures 573 and 613 K were tested in HDO of sorbitol with TOS 1 h to reveal possible changes in the composition and quantity of the products as well as in the catalytic properties of the investigated palladium systems at temperatures of their reduction (573 and 613 K). The reaction temperature growth from 573 to 613 K was accompanied by redistribution of С5+ components in terms of a number of carbon atoms without significant variations in the composition of gaseous products (Table 5). An increase in the TR value from 573 to 613 K over the Pd/WZ(1073) and Pd/WZ(1223) catalysts resulted in decrease of the yield of C5 and C6 hydrocarbons and increase of the yield of С7+ hydrocarbons (by 9.6 and 22.2 mol%, respectively) (Table 5). These results indicated that in the range of the TR values from 573 to 613 K the reaction of aldol condensation of C6 oxygenates [65] and elimination of oxygen from the products of this reaction, as well as HG of С5+ hydrocarbons occurred more intensively over both catalysts. At the same time, the Pd/WZ(1073) catalyst with higher acidity slightly promoted the yield of С7+ hydrocarbons compared to that over the Pd/WZ(1223) catalyst with lower acidity. This difference seemed to be due to the increase in temperature from 573 to 613 K led to a decrease of the yield of С9 и С9+ hydrocarbons on the Pd/WZ(1073) catalyst and an increase of the yield of these hydrocarbons on the Pd/WZ(1223) catalyst (Table 5). In addition, the Pd/WZ(1073)–613 catalyst yielded more С1–С4 alkanes (14.9 mol%) as compared to the Pd/WZ(1223)–613 catalyst (12.2 mol%) (Table 5). Thus, it can be argued that the Pd/WZ(1073)–613 catalyst enhanced hydrogenolysis and hydrocracking of С5+ hydrocarbons compared to the Pd/WZ(1223)–613 catalyst. For this reason, С5+ hydrocarbons yield over the former catalyst was slightly less (79.0 mol%) than over the latter one (81.0 mol%) (Table 5). Interestingly methanol was not found in the aqueous phase formed over the Pd/WZ(TC)–613 samples (Table 5) probably due to suppression of exothermic reactions of its synthesis from carbon oxides and hydrogen at temperature of sorbitol HDO 613 K [70]. At the same time, HDC and WGS reactions proceeded at comparable rates over the Pd/WZ(1073)–613 and Pd/WZ(1223)–613 catalysts with a similar size of palladium particles (Table 2), which was confirmed by the similar yields of both CO (4.8 and 5.1 mol%, respectively) and CO2 (1.5 and 1.7 mol%, respectively) (Table 5). As can be seen from Table 6, growth in TR values from 573 to 613 K in С5–С9 fractions obtained over Pd/WZ(1073) и Pd/WZ(1223) catalysts causes a decrease in the yield of n–alkanes (by 22.0 and 18.0 mol%, respectively) and an increase in the yield of isoalkanes (by 11.9 and 3.3 mol%, respectively) and cycloalkanes (by 9.6 and 12.7 mol%, respectively). In the studied range of the TR values, the yield of С6–С7 arenes increases by 0.6 and 0.9 mol% in the presence of the Pd/WZ(1073) and Pd/WZ(1223) samples, respectively (Table 6). In turn, the yield of С8 arenes decreases by 1.1 mol% for the Pd/WZ(1073) sample and increases by 1.7 mol% for the Pd/WZ(1223) sample (Table 6). The changes identified in the group composition of С5–С9 fractions are caused by the dehydrogenation reaction of n–alkanes enhanced by an increase in temperature, the products of which are actively converted through isomerization, cyclization, and aromatization. However, it should be noted that the Pd/WZ(1073) catalyst provides a greater yield of isoalkanes (by 11.9 mol%), and a smaller yield of cycloalkanes (by 9.6 mol%) and С6–С7 arenes (by 0.6 mol%). On the contrary, the yield of isoalkanes over the Pd/WZ(1223) catalyst increases by a smaller amount (by 3.3 mol%), and the yield of cycloalkanes and С6–С7 arenes increase by a larger amount (12.7 mol% and 0.9 mol%, respectively). These findings allow us to conclude that HG and isomerization of С5+ hydrocarbons proceed faster than cyclization, DHIS, and DH over the Pd/WZ(1073)–613 sample of higher acidity, while HG and isomerization of С5+ hydrocarbons are slower than cyclization, DHIS and DH over the Pd/WZ(1223)–613 sample of lower acidity. These differences in properties of the Pd/WZ(1073)–613 and Pd/WZ(1223)–613 samples provide a significantly higher yield of target hydrocarbons (35.2 mol%) over the first catalyst compared with that over the second one (23.2 mol%), and a lower yield of arenes (2.0 mol%) over the first catalyst compared with that over the second one (3.8 mol%) (Table 6). The results obtained showed that as the reaction temperature increased from 573 to 613 K the yield of target hydrocarbons in sorbitol HDO increased over both Pd/WZ(1073)–TR and Pd/WZ(1223)–TR catalysts. To achieve the maximum yield of target hydrocarbons and the minimum yield of arenes the preferred temperatures of WZ support calcination and sorbitol HDO over Pd/WZ(TC)–TR catalysts were found to be 1073 and 613 K, respectively. It should be noted that the Pd/WZ catalyst with the support calcination temperature of 1073 K provided a higher yield of С5+ hydrocarbons (79 mol%) at a lower reaction temperature of 613 K compared to the Pd/WO x –Al2O3 catalyst, which exhibited a lower yield of С5+ hydrocarbons (58 mol%) at a higher reaction temperature of 653 K [22]. However, the stability of the Pd/WZ(TC)–TR catalysts should be assessed to prove that the selected WZ support calcination and reaction temperatures are optimal for hydroconversion of sorbitol into fuel components. 3.3.4 Stability of Pd/WZ catalysts A set of experiments was performed to investigate the long-term stability of the Pd/WZ(TC)–TR catalyst in sorbitol HDO at similar contact time. It was found that all the studied catalysts provided almost complete sorbitol conversion within 6 h on TOS. An increase of the yield of gases and a decrease of the yield of С5+ hydrocarbons were mainly observed during long-term operation of the catalysts at 613 K (Table 5). These changes were related to a more prominent contribution of the HDC route over the Pd/WZ(1223) and Pd/WZ(1073) catalysts as well as HG reactions over the latter one. At the same time, the yield of target hydrocarbons decreased more significant after 6 h of the reaction in the presence of the Pd/WZ(1073)–573 (by 0.7 mol%) and Pd/WZ(1073)–613 (by 0.8 mol%) catalysts (Table 6). This can be attributed to decrease of isomerizing activity of these catalysts, which is evidenced by a decrease in the total yield of isoalkanes with octane numbers above 70 in the presence of the Pd/WZ(1073)–573 (by 0.5 mol%) and Pd/WZ(1073)–613) (by 1.0 mol%) catalysts. The minimum yield of target hydrocarbons 15.7 mol% was observed in the presence of the Pd/WZ(1223)–573 catalyst (Table 6). After 6 h TOS of sorbitol HDO the lowest yield of arenes was attained over the Pd/WZ(TC)–513 catalysts while application of the Pd/WZ(TC)–613 catalysts resulted in the highest arenes yield (Table 6). Apparently, an increase in reaction temperature from 573 to 613 K accelerated the rate of DHIS and DH reactions [21, 72]. At the same time less aromatic hydrocarbons were formed over the Pd/WZ(1073)–613 catalyst compared to those formed over the Pd/WZ(1223)–613 catalyst during the entire testing period (Table 6). Thus, the three catalysts Pd/WZ(1073)–573, Pd/WZ(1073)–613, and Pd/WZ(1223)–613 were shown to be the most efficient in the hydroconversion of sorbitol that were also characterized by low deactivation exhibited through the slight decrease of yield of С5+ and/or target hydrocarbons or by the increase of the yield of arenes. It should be noted that deactivation can be caused by an increase of the palladium metal particles sizes, shrinking support surface, and by formation of carbonaceous deposits on the catalyst surface [73]. To evaluate the surface change of the catalysts after 6 h TOS of sorbitol HDO, samples tested at temperatures of 573 and 613 K were analyzed by the N2 physisorption method, and their S BET values are shown in Table 1. As seen from Table 1, the decrease in the S BET of the spent Pd/WZ(1223)–TR catalysts reached 39–42% (from 31 to 18–19 m2/g), which was found to be much higher than that of the spent Pd/WZ(1073)–TR catalysts with a value of 3–6% (from 62 to 58–60 m2/g). Thus, the WZ(1223) support is less resistant to surface shrinkage during sorbitol HDO as compared to the WZ(1073) support. Note that among the products of sorbitol HDO methylcyclopentane and alkylbenzenes were reported to be typically responsible for the formation of carbonaceous deposits in reactions of isomerization, DHIS, DH, and HG [74]. In this connection, the spent Pd/WZ catalysts were studied by coulometric titration to determine the amount of carbon deposits on their surfaces. The content of coke products identified on the surfaces of spent catalysts were presented in Table 7 indicating that greater amount of deposits were formed over the Pd/WZ(1073)–TR catalysts with high acidity compared to the Pd/WZ(1223)–TR catalysts of low acidity [73]. The yield of carbon deposits on the surfaces of the Pd/WZ(1073)–TR and Pd/WZ(1223)–TR catalysts grew up as HDO temperature increased from 573 to 613 K (Table 7) [75]. The yield of С5+ hydrocarbons over the Pd/WZ(1223)–613 catalyst with a lower content of carbonaceous deposits was higher compared to that over the Pd/WZ(1073)–613 catalyst, as well as less amount of target hydrocarbons and more arenes are formed over the Pd/WZ(1073)–613 sample with a larger amount of carbonaceous deposits. Therefore, the calcination temperature 1073 K was found to be the better temperature for calcining the support as well as temperature 613 K for reducing the Pd/WZ(TC)–TR catalyst and carrying out the reaction provided better activity and selectivity to desired fuel components. It should be noted that the amount of С5+ hydrocarbons (77 mol%) formed in sorbitol HDO in the presence of the Pd/WZ(1073)–613 catalyst in 6 h TOS was greater than that formed in the presence of the Pd/WO x –Al2O3 catalyst (59 mol%) [22]. Interestingly the better calcination temperature found in current study for tungstated zirconia applied as support for the Pd/WZ(TC)–TR catalyzed sorbitol HDO corresponded to that previously reported for the WZ support used for the Pd catalyst applied in isomerization of n–hexane [29,42]. 4 Conclusions One-pot continuous hydrodeoxygenation of sorbitol to fuel components was studied over Pd/WO x –ZrO2 catalysts focusing on the effect of the calcination temperature of tungstated zirconia, Pd catalyst reduction temperature, HDO reaction temperature as well as correlation between their physical-chemical properties and fuel hydrocarbons yield. It was shown that Pd catalysts supported on tungstated zirconia calcined in the temperature domain 1073–1223 K provided complete hydroconversion of sorbitol into fuel components (С5+ hydrocarbons with a yield of 76–81 mol%) under selected reaction conditions, such as 573–613 K, hydrogen pressure of 4.0 MPa and WHSV of 1.0 h–1 within 6 h TOS. The amount of target hydrocarbons comprising isoalkanes and cycloalkanes was shown to depend on the temperatures of WZ support calcination and Pd catalyst reduction. The yield of the target and aromatic hydrocarbons over the catalyst on the basis of the tungstated zirconia calcined at 1073 K was higher than that for the catalyst with the support calcination temperature of 1223 K, yielding 17 and 2 mol% versus 16 and 1 mol%, respectively, at the reaction temperature of 573 K. An increase of reaction temperature from 573 to 613 K gave a rise of target hydrocarbons and arenes due to more intensive reactions of isomerization, cyclization, and aromatization of n–alkanes affording 34 and 2 mol% as well as 24 and 3 mol% yields, respectively, with the support calcination temperature of 1073 K and 1223 K. The maximum yield of the desired isoalkanes and cycloalkanes with RON>70 (34 mol%) along with the minimum amount of undesirable C6–C8 arenes (2 mol%) was obtained at 613 K over Pd catalyst reduced at 613 K using tungstated zirconia calcined at 1073 K. Such conditions provided formation of Pd/WO x –ZrO2 catalyst with an optimal texture, acidity and dispersion of catalytic active sites as indicated by different physicochemical methods (XRD, low temperature N2 physical adsorption, NH3–TPD, H2–TPR, CO chemisorption, XPS, and CO2–TPD). coredata.dc:description: The one-pot hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) of an aqueous sorbitol solution (20 wt%) was studied over Pd (0.5 wt%)/WO x –ZrO2 catalyst at the variable reaction conditions in a continuous mode focusing on the effect of the calcination temperature of tungstated zirconia (1073 and 1223 К), the Pd containing catalyst reduction temperature, as well as on the correlation between their physical-chemical properties and fuel hydrocarbons yield. It was found that sorbitol HDO under reaction conditions such as temperatures 573 and 613 K, hydrogen pressure 4.0 MPa, and WHSV of 1.0 h–1 resulted in the highest yield of C5+ hydrocarbons 76–81 mol% mainly consisting of isoalkanes, cycloalkanes, n–alkanes and arenes. The maximum yield of the targeted isoalkanes and cycloalkanes with RON>70 (34 mol%) along with the minimum amount of undesirable C6–C8 arenes (2 mol%) were obtained at 613 K. Under these conditions the Pd catalyst reduced at 613 K using tungstated zirconia calcined at 1073 K as a support afforded formation of Pd/WO x –ZrO2 with the optimal microtexture, acidity and dispersion of catalytically active phase. Physicochemical properties of the catalyst and support were studied by XRD, low temperature N2 physical adsorption, NH3–TPD, H2–TPR, CO chemisorption, XPS, and CO2–TPD.
coredata.dc:title: Continuous one-pot hydrodeoxygenation of sorbitol to fuel components over Pd/WO x –ZrO2 catalysts
